posts.cooked:
If I make a call using conventional mobile network and the callee‚Äôs phone is offline, I hear a message about the callee status or else a voicemail etc. depending on what the callee‚Äôs divert settings are.
However if I make a Signal call it rings no matter what the state of the callee‚Äôs phone. Given that a Signal message has message delivery and read status blobs why is the call function so ‚Äòdumb‚Äô?

The impact of this is that I have no idea why a callee is not answering a call which is important if they are vulnerable.

There once was e great feature for this: a different sound during the time the call gets established and another one when the phone was really ringing. This made it really easy to hear whether the other phone was ringing or not. But it was removed without reason and makes confusion since then.

See this discussion for more info.

link_counts.title: Submarine sound gone... ring sound before connection made

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Signal currently says calling when trying to connect to a user and ringing when they‚Äôre device is ringing. On Desktop there is no distinction.

The statement from Greyson:

Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.33 release Android Beta Feedback
Some background on the sonar ping decision: I‚Äôm going to claim that the vast majority of people have no idea what that sound really means. You folks do because you‚Äôre in the know, but the average user doesn‚Äôt know/care. User‚Äôs don‚Äôt know/care because other calling apps don‚Äôt have this separate sound either, so it can be confusing when they hear it in Signal. It makes call connection times feel longer, even when they‚Äôre relatively quick. If you‚Äôre ever curious what state you‚Äôre in, you can stil‚Ä¶

link_counts.title: Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.33 release

posts.cooked:
@Whatnoww tx I never knew that. Of course a visual indicator is really only of use if one is using a handsfree method.
However for me ‚Äúcalling‚Äù and ‚Äúringing‚Äù in this context are synonymous. I wonder why it doesn‚Äôt say ‚ÄúConnecting‚Äù instead as that‚Äôs pretty unambiguous.

OK I managed to follow this issue in the tortuous beta catch-all thread and then it went off to Submarine sound gone... ring sound before connection made and then it made it into a feature request Different sound for dialing vs. ringing and then someone even made a PR Enhance call sounds: Reduce backgroundnoise on ringing sounds, reduce filesize, reintroduce 'connecting' sound, add 'call ended' sound by Meteor0id ¬∑ Pull Request #8948 ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Android ¬∑ GitHub.

I can kinda see why devs ditched the old sonar sound while ‚Äòconnecting/dialling/calling‚Äô as they thought it might generate some confusion but unfortunately they simultaneously managed to break the standard paradigm for calling a phone i.e. the caller never hears a ringing tone until the connection is made to the callee‚Äôs phone and it actually rings. Unfort the insta-ring is what WA also does.

link_counts.title: Submarine sound gone... ring sound before connection made
Different sound for dialing vs. ringing

Enhance call sounds: Reduce backgroundnoise on ringing sounds, reduce filesize, reintroduce 'connecting' sound, add 'call ended' sound by Meteor0id ¬∑ Pull Request #8948 ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Android ¬∑ GitHub

posts.cooked:
Mr-Brunes:

the standard paradigm for calling a phone i.e. the caller never hears a ringing tone until the connection is made to the callee‚Äôs phone and it actually rings

Maybe for landlines years ago, but that definitely hasn‚Äôt been the case in a long time for mobile phones. The caller hears a ringing tone as soon as their call is being placed, but depending on network conditions, the recipient‚Äôs phone may not start ringing right away. This can be tested easily. I just tried it myself and my calling phone was playing a ringing tone a good 3 seconds before my other phone actually started ringing.

A few seconds of latency while the caller‚Äôs phone ringer app is unslumbered by Android‚Äôs ever-increasingly aggressive power-saving algorithm is to be expected.

However if the phone is off or in airplane mode then posts in the below thread indicate that the observed case for conventional mobile/cell calls is that the ringing tone is definitely not heard until the device actually rings.

Submarine sound gone... ring sound before connection made Android Discussion
(if signal team is deadset against Sonar) Why not drop the RingRing CallBack Tone and its inheritance of expectations from calling. and use a different tone entirely, I found this, public domain sound, (random suggestion) Any other tune is also applicable, the above is just a sample. Almost repeating myself, regarding usability to other messaging apps, the following image is showing in an abstract way, the logical usage share, [Untitled%201] My main problems were, I called someone ‚Ä¶

In the UK, if the mobile/cell callee‚Äôs phone is offline then the caller hears a delay and then variance between staccato beeps, silence, a message indicating device unreachability or voicemail.

It seems like Signal is missing a trick here. Rather than just copying WA and forgetting that two wrongs don‚Äôt make a right, why not make a feature of the known differences between CALL_OUTGOING and CALL_RINGING and, similarly to the messaging delivery status indicators, clearly (ahem) call them out as a new Call Connection Status feature so that the reality is known?

link_counts.title: Submarine sound gone... ring sound before connection made

posts.cooked:
To be honest, this submarine ringtone annoys me. Is there a particular reason why this tone was chosen? I also use Threema. In my opinion, this ringtone is more contemporary. You really have the feeling that a telephone is ringing.

Well, as with everything, it‚Äôs a matter of individual taste.
Maybe one day there will be a different ringtone after all. I cross my fingers.

achap:

To be honest, this submarine ringtone annoys me. Is there a particular reason why this tone was chosen?

Are you posting from the past? They aren‚Äôt using the ‚Äúsonar ping‚Äù anymore.

If I had to guess, they probably chose to do that because Signal was ‚Äúsearching‚Äù for the recipient (but not really ‚Äì just trying to connect).

Herohtar:

Are you posting from the past? They aren‚Äôt using the ‚Äúsonar ping‚Äù anymore.

Thanks for the hint. You‚Äôre right, of course‚Ä¶ I must have just had a temporary time shift. But what is the name of the current ringtone they are using in the app? I don‚Äôt know if others feel the same way, the ringtone sounds a bit harsh to me.

posts.name: Sky R
posts.cooked:
Put the other phone in Airplane Mode,
then make a regular call (a feature of every smartphone on the planet) to that phone,
what happens ‚Ä¶ ?

p.s. Sorry for late reply, I checked my email today, noticed the notification mail and ‚Ä¶

It may be useful to know that WhatsApp have finally fixed this behaviour i.e. when a call is at the ‚Äòcalling‚Äô stage the caller hears no ringing tone - it is silent. The ringing tone is only heard by the caller when the call status goes to ‚ÄòRinging‚Äô i.e. the callee‚Äôs phone is actually ringing.

The previous stance on this behaviour appeared to be to copy whatever Whatsapp did, so can we follow suit please?

Mr-Brunes:

It may be useful to know that WhatsApp have finally fixed this behaviour i.e. when a call is at the ‚Äòcalling‚Äô stage the caller hears no ringing tone - it is silent. The ringing tone is only heard by the caller when the call status goes to ‚ÄòRinging‚Äô i.e. the callee‚Äôs phone is actually ringing.

I could really get used to that.

Could this still be implemented in Signal at this point, or would it be too much work for the programmers?
